contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox hospital | Name = Valley Hospital Medical Center | Org/Group = [[Universal Health Services]] | Image = <!-- optional --> | Caption = <!-- optional --> | Logo = | Location = | Region = [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] | State = Nevada | Country = US | map_type = United States Downtown Las Vegas | latitude = 36.163056 | longitude = -115.166111 | map_caption = Location in Las Vegas | HealthCare = Private | Type = Community | Speciality = <!-- if devoted to a speciality, i.e. not if has broad spectrum of specialities --> | Standards = <!-- optional if no national standards --> | Emergency = Yes | Affiliation= Touro University Nevada | Helipad = {{Airport codes|||NV53|p=n}} | Beds = 409 | Founded = 1972 | Closed = <!-- optional --> | Website = [http://www.valleyhospital.net/Home www.valleyhospital.net] | Wiki-Links = <!-- optional --> |}} The '''Valley Hospital Medical Center''', commonly known as Valley Hospital, is a [[for-profit hospital]] owned and operated by [[Universal Health Services]]. The 409-bed hospital is located in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. ==History== The hospital was founded in 1972. Established [[Southern Nevada]]'s first [[air ambulance]] service, ''[[Flight for Life]]'', which was owned by [[Metro Aviation]], in 1980. On December 4, 2001, Valley Hospital ended its contract with Metro Aviation, shutting down the ''Flight for Life'' air ambulance service, and retiring the [[helipad]]. Valley Hospital completed a new helipad next to the emergency department with a grassy area in 2007. Valley’s ''Emergency Critical Care Center'' increased the number of beds from 28 to 42 on March 11, 2004. This project was completed when 11 urgent care beds were added to the center in June. ==Services== *Cardiac Center *Valley Hospital Medical Center Heliport {{Airport codes|||NV53|p=n}} *[[Obstetrics]]/[[Gynaecology|Gynecology]]/ Level III [[Neonatal intensive-care unit|Neonatal Intensive Care Unit]] (NICU) ==Helipad== {{Infobox airport | name = Valley Hospital Medical Center Helipad | FAA = NV53 | type = Helipad | owner = | operator = Valley Hospital Medical Center | city-served = | location = Las Vegas, Nevada | elevation-f = 2,055 | elevation-m = 626 | coordinates = {{coord|36|09|47|N|115|09|56|W|type:airport_scale:5000_region:US-NV}} | website = | h1-number = H1 | h1-length-f = 54 × 48 | h1-length-m = {{convert|54|x|48|ft|abbr=on|disp=output number only}} | h1-surface = [[concrete]] | h2-number = H2 | h2-length-f = 60 × 60 | h2-length-m = {{convert|60|x|60|ft|abbr=on|disp=output number only}} | h2-surface = [[concrete]] | stat-year = | stat1-header = | stat1-data = | stat2-header = | stat2-data = | footnotes = Sources: [[Airnav.com]]<ref>{{AirNav|NV53}}</ref> }} From 1980 to 2001, the helipad was located on top of the hospital, adjacent to the lobby. After "Flight for Life" was sold to "[[Air Methods|Mercy Air Services]]" in 2001, the hospital created a landing zone just south of the emergency entrance in a dirt lot for Mercy Air's bigger helicopters. In 2007 the hospital refurbished an old parking lot into a grassy area, complete with a new helipad right in front of the emergency entrance. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.valleyhospital.net/Home Valley Hospital website] {{Las Vegas hospitals}} [[Category:1972 establishments in Nevada]] [[Category:Hospitals in Las Vegas, Nevada]] [[Category:Hospitals established in 1972]]
